title: Clique with short period: "fat" long running transactions are never processed (always interrupted)
body:
The issue might be related to the code
https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/blob/master/miner/worker.go#L723

So "fat" long running transactions are always get interrupted, never processed and stuck in txpool as pending

But it might be expected behavior of Clique consensus :(

#### System information
```
Version: 1.8.26-stable
Git Commit: cdae1c59abc32f85debfa29577fbf1ed036ebf73
Architecture: amd64
Protocol Versions: [63 62]
Network Id: 1
Go Version: go1.11.5
```
OS & Version: Windows/Linux


#### Expected behaviour
transaction processed, block mined with a delay

#### Actual behaviour
transaction is never processed, block mined within usual `clique period`

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour
- prepare PoA network with clique period: 1s
- submit "fat" `tx` with processing time >> clique period

CC @rjl493456442 @karalabe @holiman @fjl @yuriytkach @pra-github

In theory, if the fat transaction can be broadcasted to all sealer nodes, it can be included.

I have 4 sealer nodes + 1 gw node
and I send `tx` only to that `gw` node

The transaction should be broadcasted through the `gw` node to all sealer nodes. If so, no matter how much the clique period is, the worker will execute the tx first and then throw out the block into the network.

The interruption could only happen some sealer nodes send the empty block without including the fat tx.

well, hard to comment but
- all 5 nodes have 4 peers
- all nodes have 1 pending `tx` when it stuck
- 1 node PoA network in `--dev`  mode have same issue and I can generate more logs in this mode

I will be closing this issue as works-as-intended/wont-fix. If a transaction takes more time to execute than the block time, that is a DoS attack, since the entire network will be stuck processing it while the chain moves forward. The same transaction will wreck havoc in the pending blocks even if not mined, since nodes will keep trying to execute it and getting interrupted (or not), causing wasted CPU usage. Lastly if multiple miners seal blocks with such a transaction, that would cause reorgs that take many many blocks to actually execute and finalize, again DoSing the chain.

Unfortunately the way Ethereum selects the best/heaviest chain is incompatible with blocks exceeding their allotted time. The best solution is to split up such huge transactions into multiple smaller ones that fit in a block: for normal contract execution, add support for yielding and continuing where a previous left off; for contract deployment split it into multiple cooperating contracts.
